addressleaf.section:
To my L. T
re
r by
e post
e 19 & 20 of August 1592.

page.lettertext:
fol.274r
Belgia 1592 20 August To my L. Trea
s
by
[.]
Post
May it please your good L. Her
Ma
ties
l
re
to
e states of
e 23 of
e last, w
t
an other from your L. of
e 24 of
e same, came no sooner
unto me then two dayes agoe. They were brought unto me hither,
by
e old Englishe post, w
ch
was lately w
t
your L. who receaved them,
he sayeth, about 4 dayes before, of one
George Halle
S
r
Francis Veres
servaunt, to whome they were delivered, as
e post had understoode
by a man of
S
r
Thomas Shirley
. There were two thinges
noted by your L. in
at l
re
w
ch
I writte
e 15 of July, That I dispatched
it before I had
e answear of
e
States,
whome first it had bin fitte,
I should have earnestly urged, to take some p
nt
resolution: and
at
in
e l
re
s w
ch
her Hig
nes
written unto
e States, I c
o
ceaved a further
scruple, then
e l
re
gave occasion. I beseeche your L. for
e first
to give me so muche credit,
at I did my duty thoroughly, in requiring
their answear: as I doe allwayes
e like, in affaires of any moment,
though I happen to omitte to signify such pointes. For I p
nt
ed
her Hig
nes
l
re
e 14 of
e forsaid moneth, and I sent yow their answear
w
t
in two dayes after: w
ch
I doe seldome gette so soone, but w
t
great
importunitie. For they say they are a multitude, and in matters
of importance they can not so resolve, as her M
tie
may alone.
And as for writing before,
at I receaved their answear, when I could
not have it p
nt
ly, nor so certainty otherwise, when they would
exhibit it, I thought I should doe best for c
o
tenting your L. to
advertise w
t
e soonest howe I had proceeded, and w
at
I thought of
their purpose, and yet still to goe forward in soliciting their answear,
w
ch
I sent
e next day after. I hope your L. is
suaded,
at for
mine owne understanding I was not troubled w
t
any scruple in her
M
ties
l
re
s. For I knewe directly w
at
was meant, by those that I
receaved, and so I signified sufficiently in my publicke dealing w
t
e States. But being heere where I sawe how muche it went
against their mindes, and finding
at
e l
re
was not altogether
emptory, but indited in suche wordes, as seemed in
e reading to
include a kinde of liberty, I hope your L. will conceave,
at
e maner
of my suspition, in respect of their construction, was not founded
upon nothing. True it is
at her M
tie
writte enough, both at
e time and before, wherby
e
they might
ceave,
at her meaning
was no other, but to send for
e c
o
panies: yet it was not in
e l
re
in
at resolut maner, as if she would not be refused, or as her Hig
nes
fol.274v
heeretofore in suche other her demaundes hath signified ex
p
ssely.
And although it was sufficient
at I declared it unto them, because
they were referred to
e pointes of my instructions, yet knowing
they were inclyned to stand upon deniall, I could not but imagine,
at they would helpe themselves in every sort, w
t
any wordes of
apparance of advantage unto them. And so it proved by theyr
answear. I did yesterday deliver her M
ties
l
re
s, w
ch
they thought very strange to come so slowly to their handes,
for
at there have bin many passages sins
e l
re
was written, and
divers l
res
heere receaved about 18 dayes before,
at were dated
in
London
about
e self same time. I doe assure your L. the
slacknes of suche messengers, w
ch
happeneth very often, doth make
me leese
e opportunities, of effecting suche thinges as her M
tie
re
q
reth. For here they gaine by suche meanes a great deale
of time, and devise how to crosse her M
ties
intent, w
ch
might passe
haps at first w
t
lesse opposition. What answear they will
make, I cane not learne, nor conjecture. For although I have
bin instant in re
q
ring it of them, they say they must have
time to deliberat w
t
themselves: and I finde them allwayes
one in their unwilling disposition. Your L. last unto
me was written
e 28 of July, and I receaved it heere the 11 of
this p
nt
, returning an answear
e very same day. The
occurrences of
Coevoerden
doe better every day, and
e place, there
is no doubt, will be owrs very shortly, unles
e Enemy make a [.]
w
ch
e bruite is, he doth purpose. For
e speeche is given out, [that]
there are in readines to passe
e Rhine 22 Enseignes of Spania[rds]
16 Dutche, and 6 of Wallons, w
t
400 horse, w
ch
are thought w[ ill ]
amount, w
t
e troupes of
Verdugo
, to 5000 men: whereof we lo[ok]
every houre to be better informed.
Count Philip
of [.]
is returned out of
France
, w
t
all his Captaines and compani[es]
They are judged to be at
e lest 1300 men.
Mons[ieur]
Buzenval
hath bin this morning w
t
e States, w
t
l
re
s from [.]
to pray to loane of so muche mony, as may suffice for 4 mor[e .]
to intertene 3000 foote: and w
t
all to spare him three of th[e]
greater shippes of warre, and two pinaces to lie in
e Sen[e]
e space of 3 monethes. He had no other answear
fol.275r
at
e
Provinces
must be moved: Howbeit I am
suaded, they
will take some p
nt
order for sending
e shippes: and will procure
w
t
good speede a c
o
petent summe of mony.
And thus for this p
nt
I take my humble leave. 19 Au
g
1592.
